title: Philippine oriole
text:
The Philippine oriole ("Oriolus steerii") or grey-throated oriole, is a species of <a href="bird">bird</a> in the family <a href="Oriolidae">Oriolidae</a>.
It is <a href="Endemism">endemic</a> to the Philippines.
Its natural <a href="habitat">habitat</a> is subtropical or tropical moist lowland <a href="forest">forest</a>s. The species is fairly common throughout its range, but the Cebu race ("O. s. assimilis") was last sighted in 1906 and is now classified as <a href="extinct">extinct</a>.
Taxonomy and systematics.
First described by <a href="Richard%20Bowdler%20Sharpe">Richard Bowdler Sharpe</a> in 1877, the Philippine oriole is a member of the genus "<a href="Oriolus">Oriolus</a>". Some authorities have considered it to be <a href="conspecific">conspecific</a> with, or as a subspecies of, the <a href="dark-throated%20oriole">dark-throated oriole</a>. These two species may form a <a href="Species%20complex">superspecies</a> with the <a href="Isabela%20oriole">Isabela oriole</a>.
Subspecies.
Five <a href="subspecies">subspecies</a> are recognized: 
Description.
The Philippine oriole is a yellowish-brown bird with mainly thin feathers on the upper side of its body, a red beak and red eyes as well.
Distribution and habitat.
Endemic to the Philippines, the Philippine oriole is found in forest, forest edge and second growth in the lowlands of Masbate, Samar, Leyte, Semirara Island, Negros, Bohol, Mindanao, Basilan and the Sulu Archipelago.
Behaviour and ecology.
This species, as much like with other <a href="Oriolus">orioles</a>, tend to have a diet of mainly grass, flowers and similar food.
